div.div: NoSQL databases are generally scalable due to distribution of data among hosts. Since it is usually cheaper to buy more machines rather than to buy more powerful machines (law of diminishing returns), scalability also makes NoSQL more economical.
Main disadvantages could be maturity (often key features missing), availability of support (often open-source), expertise (low number of NoSQL experts).

note.div:
CAP theorem states that any distributed data store can provide at most two of the following three guarantees:
Consistency = all clients see the same data, regardless of which node they connect to
Availability = all requests received by a non-failing node must result in a response
Partition tolerance = the system continues to operate despite arbitrary number of messages being dropped by the network between nodes

Consistency and Availability is not realizable in distributed systems with number of nodes larger than 1.
Examples: MySQL, PostgreSQL

Available and Partition tolerance - request sent by the user to view or modify the data present in the database nodes are not dropped and are processed in presence of a network partition
Examples: DynamoDB

Consistency and Partition tolerance - requests sent by the user to view or modify the data present in the database nodes are dropped instead of responding with inconsistent data in presence of a network partition
Example: MongoDB, Redis

ul.li: Vertical scaling (scaling-up) = buying bigger servers as load increases
Horizontal scaling (scaling-out) = buying more servers as load increases

note.div:
Replication = data is duplicated betwen nodes
Primary-Replica (master server handles writes, replicas sync for read)
Multi-Primary (multiple servers handle reads and writes)
Good for read-heavy applications

Sharding = data is split between independent nodes, for example user accounts could be split by region
That also means Cross-Shard Queries are expensive
Good for write-heavy applications

ul.li: Basically Available (concurrently accessible at all times)
Soft-state (observed state may change without external input)
Eventually consistent (reads from different node will be consistent at some point)

note.div:
ACID is relatively simple to maintain, whereas BASE is fairly difficult (requires conflict resolution over multiple copies of distributed data).
SQL databases are almost uniformly ACID compliant, NoSQL databases tend to conform to BASE.
